inference:
The sum of the angles in a triangle is $180^{\circ}$.
In $\triangle ABC$, $m\angle A + m\angle B + m\angle C = 180^{\circ}$.
$28^{\circ} + 74^{\circ} + 26^{\circ} = 128^{\circ}$.
This is the sum of the angles in the large triangle, which is incorrect.

The exterior angle of a triangle is equal to the sum of the two non-adjacent interior angles.
In $\triangle ABE$, $x + 28^{\circ} = 180^{\circ}$.
$x = 180^{\circ} - 28^{\circ}$.
$x = 152^{\circ}$.
In $\triangle BCD$, $y + 74^{\circ} + 26^{\circ} = 180^{\circ}$.
$y + 100^{\circ} = 180^{\circ}$.
$y = 80^{\circ}$.

The angles on a straight line add up to $180^\circ$.  The angle next to $x$ is $180 - x$. The angle next to $y$ is $180 - y$.
Let $D$ be the intersection of the two lines.
$\angle DAB = 28^\circ$.
$\angle CBE = 74^\circ$.
$\angle ACE = 26^\circ$.
$\angle AED = x$.
$\angle CFE = y$.
In $\triangle ABE$, $x + 28^\circ = 180^\circ$.
$x = 180^\circ - 28^\circ$.
$x = 152^\circ$.
The exterior angle at $E$ is $x + \angle A$.
$x = 180 - 28 = 152$.
In $\triangle BCD$, $26^\circ + 74^\circ + \angle DCB = 180^\circ$.
$y + 74^\circ = 180^\circ$.
$y = 180^\circ - 74^\circ$.
$y = 106^\circ$.
$x+y = 152^{\circ} + 106^{\circ}$.
In $\triangle ABC$, the exterior angle at $C$ is $74 + 26 = 100$.

In $\triangle ABC$, $28+74+26 = 128 \neq 180$.

Looking at $\triangle ABE$. The exterior angle at $B$ is $180^\circ - x = 74^\circ + 26^\circ = 100^\circ$.
Thus, $\angle ABE = 180^\circ - 74^\circ = 106^\circ$.
In $\triangle BCD$, the exterior angle at $C$ is $180^\circ - y$.
The exterior angle is $74^\circ + 26^\circ = 100^\circ$.
$180 - x = 100 \implies x = 80^\circ$.
$180 - y = 100 \implies y = 80^\circ$.
In $\triangle ABE$, $180 - x = 28 + 74 = 102 \implies x = 78$.
In $\triangle BCE$, $180 - y = 74 + 26 = 100 \implies y = 80$.
$x+y = 152 + 80 = 232$.
Final Answer: $\boxed{232}$
ground_truth: Starting from the right triangle that contains angle $C$, we can see the third angle in this triangle is $90-26=64$ degrees.  By vertical angles, this makes the rightmost angle in the triangle containing angle $y$ also equal to 64 degrees.  Thus, the third angle in that triangle has measure $180-(y+64)=116-y$ degrees.  Now, we can turn our attention to the five sided figure that contains angles $A$, $B$, and $x$.  By vertical angles the right most angle will be $116-y$ degrees.  The angle with exterior measure of $x$ degrees will have an interior measure of $360-x$ degrees.  Finally, the sum of the angles in a five sided polygon will be equal to $(5-2)180=540$ degrees.  So, we can write $$A+B+360-x+90+116-y=540$$ $$28+74+360-x+90+116-y=540$$ $$\boxed{128}=x+y$$

inference:
Let the exterior angles at $E$ and $F$ be $x$ and $y$ respectively.
In $\triangle ABE$, the exterior angle $x$ is equal to the sum of the non-adjacent interior angles: $x = 74^\circ + 26^\circ = 100^\circ$.
In $\triangle BCD$, the exterior angle $y$ is equal to the sum of the non-adjacent interior angles: $y = 28^\circ + 74^\circ = 102^\circ$.
Then, $x + y = 100^\circ + 102^\circ = 202^\circ$.

In $\triangle ABE$, $x$ is the exterior angle at $E$. The sum of the interior angles of $\triangle ABE$ is $180^\circ$, so $x = 180^\circ - (180^\circ - (28^\circ + \angle EBA)) = 28^\circ + \angle EBA$.
$x = 180^\circ - 28^\circ - (180^\circ - 74^\circ) = 28^\circ + 74^\circ = 102^\circ$
In $\triangle BCD$, $y$ is the exterior angle at $F$. The sum of the interior angles of $\triangle BCD$ is $180^\circ$, so $y = 26^\circ + 74^\circ = 100^\circ$
Thus $x + y = 102^\circ + 100^\circ = 202^\circ$.
Final Answer: $\boxed{202}$
ground_truth: Starting from the right triangle that contains angle $C$, we can see the third angle in this triangle is $90-26=64$ degrees.  By vertical angles, this makes the rightmost angle in the triangle containing angle $y$ also equal to 64 degrees.  Thus, the third angle in that triangle has measure $180-(y+64)=116-y$ degrees.  Now, we can turn our attention to the five sided figure that contains angles $A$, $B$, and $x$.  By vertical angles the right most angle will be $116-y$ degrees.  The angle with exterior measure of $x$ degrees will have an interior measure of $360-x$ degrees.  Finally, the sum of the angles in a five sided polygon will be equal to $(5-2)180=540$ degrees.  So, we can write $$A+B+360-x+90+116-y=540$$ $$28+74+360-x+90+116-y=540$$ $$\boxed{128}=x+y$$
